Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday, £6 June, 1903.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr SPEAKER took the chair at 2.30 with

Speaker: NA
Text: p.m., and read prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: PETITIONS.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr SYDNEY SMITH presented a peti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion from Magnus Gold ring, agent, of Syd-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney, praying the House to inquire into cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain ' alleged grievances in regard to the

Speaker: NA
Text: administration of the Customs Department,

Speaker: NA
Text: and to grant him redress by procuring the

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment of a nominal defendant to en-

Speaker: NA
Text: able him to pursue an action against the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCCOLL presented a petition from

Speaker: NA
Text: certain residents on the northern and -

Speaker: NA
Text: southern banks of the Murray, between

Speaker: NA
Text: Albury and Wentworth, praying the House

Speaker: NA
Text: to cause steps to be taken for the locking

Speaker: NA
Text: - and utilization of the waters of that river.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received and read.

Speaker: NA
Text: PACIFIC ISLAND LABOURERS ACT.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Text: I n paragraph 6 of a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munication made by Lord Tennyson, when

Speaker: NA
Text: acting Governor-General, to tlie Secretary

Speaker: NA
Text: of State for the Colonies, dated Melbourne,

Speaker: NA
Text: 30th September, 1902, the following sen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tence occurs:-

Speaker: NA
Text: lt seems to me important that these regula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions should be drawn up and approved or by

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament as explanatory of the Kanaka Bill be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore the Royal assent is given.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to know from the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: whether that suggestion; and the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munication, generally, was despatched by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Governor-General on the advice of his

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible Ministers? I f the Governor-

Speaker: NA
Text: General was not acting on such advice, has

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister communicated with him

Speaker: NA
Text: in such a way as will protect the rights of

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible government within the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth ?

Speaker: Sir EDMUND BARTON
Text: The de-

Speaker: NA
Text: spatch in question has not been considered

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Cabinet; but I have ascertained from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Governor-General that, although it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been included among the papers laid before

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament in England, it was confidential.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Text: I t is not so marked.

Speaker: Sir EDMUND BARTON
Text: I t does not '

Speaker: NA
Text: appear to be so marked, but His Excellency

Speaker: NA
Text: assures me that that is the fact. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member asked me whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: hod advised His Excellency the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor-General in tliis - matter. Upon

Speaker: NA
Text: that point I may say that the despatch was '

Speaker: NA
Text: evidently written by His Excellency confi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dentially, in the course of his own relations

Speaker: NA
Text: the Secretary of State for the Colonies.

Speaker: NA
Text: With respect to communications of that

Speaker: NA
Text: kind it is.not the practice to consult Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters.

Speaker: NA
Text: PRESS ACCOMMODATION.

Speaker: Mr SYDNEY SMITH
Text: Som e days ago

Speaker: NA
Text: I brought under your notice, Mr Speaker, the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that the press representatives from the

Speaker: NA
Text: other States were being put to considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: inconvenience owing to their having no

Speaker: NA
Text: room set apart for their use. I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: you arc anxious to do everything you can

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide facilities for those who have

Speaker: NA
Text: duties to perform in connexion with our

Speaker: NA
Text: proceedings; but as three or four weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: have elapsed, and no room has been allotted

Speaker: NA
Text: to these press representatives, I should be

Speaker: NA
Text: very glad i f you could see your wa)' to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet their wishes as speedily as possible.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: ! fully recognise the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of providing for the press repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives a room, i f possible on the same

Speaker: NA
Text: floor as this chamber, in which the}' can

Speaker: NA
Text: transcribe their notes. Several of the press

Speaker: NA
Text: representatives waited upon me at the

Speaker: NA
Text: beginning of the session with regard to this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter, and T told them that i f there was

Speaker: NA
Text: any room on this side of the building that

Speaker: NA
Text: would be suitable for their purposes, they

Speaker: NA
Text: need only direct my attention to it, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: would place i t at their disposal. I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that there is no such room available,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I can, therefore, do nothing. I believe,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, that there is a probability of

Speaker: NA
Text: another room on the other side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: building, which is not under my control,

Speaker: NA
Text: being placed at their disposal shortly.

Speaker: NA
Text: ELECTORAL ROLLS.

Speaker: Mr SKENE
Text: the Minister for Home

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs, upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: Whether he has any intention of affording the

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal electors of Victoria a similar opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: to that which he is giving the electors of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales to inspect the rolls at the various

Speaker: NA
Text: post-offices throughout the State ; and, if not,

Speaker: NA
Text: does he intend by any other means whatever to

Speaker: NA
Text: attempt to correct the apparently inaccurate rolls

Speaker: NA
Text: upon which the maps forfcheredistribution of

Speaker: NA
Text: electorates in the State of Victoria are based ?

Speaker: Sir EDMUND BARTON
Text: Th e answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to the honorable member's question, supplied

Speaker: NA
Text: to me by the Minister for Home Affairs, is

Speaker: NA
Text: as follows :-

Speaker: NA
Text: The franchise of New South Wales closely

Speaker: NA
Text: approximates to that of the Commonwealth, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the rolls of that State are being utilized very

Speaker: NA
Text: largely by me at a trifling expense, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: Victorian franchise diverges to such an extent

Speaker: NA
Text: from that of the Commonwealth that the rolls are

Speaker: NA
Text: of little or no service for the purposes of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: parison, and ascertaining what male or female

Speaker: NA
Text: electors liave been omitted by the police in their

Speaker: NA
Text: canvass. The printing of the rolls collected by

Speaker: NA
Text: the police would involve an expenditure of £3,500,

Speaker: NA
Text: and would be in such a form (the State districts)

Speaker: NA
Text: that they could nofc be utilized for any other

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose in the Electoral Act subsequently. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am, however, preparing lists showing the names

Speaker: NA
Text: of electors grouped round polling places, which

Speaker: NA
Text: will be placed in the hands of the printer within

Speaker: NA
Text: few days, and as soon as printed will be exhibited

Speaker: NA
Text: at post-offices, State schools, and police offices,

Speaker: NA
Text: for the information of electors, who will thus be

Speaker: NA
Text: in a position to ascertain whether their names

Speaker: NA
Text: have been included or nofc. This is being done in

Speaker: NA
Text: anticipation of the Revision Court, which cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: be held until after the divisions of the State have

Speaker: NA
Text: been approved by both Houses of Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: FEMALE TELEPHON E OPERATORS.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCDONALD, for Mr HUGHES, asked

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Home Affairs, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Whether the female telephone operators in

Speaker: NA
Text: the New South Wales General Post-office have

Speaker: NA
Text: to pass any examination before being eligible to

Speaker: NA
Text: receive the minimum wage of £110 per annum?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. If not, whether there are any qualifications

Speaker: NA
Text: other than age and length of service iis pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed by fche Commonwealth Public Service

Speaker: NA
Text: Act?

Speaker: Sir EDMUND BARTON
Text: Theanswer s

Speaker: NA
Text: to the honorable and learned member's

Speaker: NA
Text: questions, supplied fco me by the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Home Affairs, are as follow :-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. No other qualifications are required than

Speaker: NA
Text: length of service and age.

Speaker: NA
Text: SUPPLY (Formal).

Speaker: NA
Text: GOLDRING CASE : INCREMENTS TO VICTORIAN

Speaker: NA
Text: PUBLIC SERVANTS : GOVERNOR-GENERAL'S

Speaker: NA
Text: DESPATCH : TELEPHONE AND TELEGRAPH

Speaker: NA
Text: SERVICES : SUBLETTING MAIL CONTRACTS :

Speaker: NA
Text: DEFENCE REGULATIONS : TRANSCONTINEN-

Speaker: NA
Text: TAL RAILWAY : MILITARY EQUIPMENT :

Speaker: NA
Text: MINIMU MWAGE : CUSTOMS ADMINISTRA-

Speaker: NA
Text: TION : FREMANTLE POST OFFICE AND CUS-

Speaker: NA
Text: TOMS HOUSE.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question-Tha t Mr Speaker, do now

Speaker: NA
Text: leave the chair, and that the House resolve

Speaker: NA
Text: itself into Committee of Supply-proposed .

Speaker: Mr SYDNEY SMITH
Text: Macquarie) -

Speaker: NA
Text: I desire to bring under the notice of honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members a matter of very great im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portance. I asked the Attorney-General

Speaker: NA
Text: a question some days ago with reference to

Speaker: NA
Text: the case of Mr Goldring, and the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: in his reply mentioned that the case was

Speaker: NA
Text: then sub judice, because certain proceedings

Speaker: NA
Text: had been instituted against the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I have since consulted the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able and learned member for Illawarra,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable and learned member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Parkes, and the honorable and learned

Speaker: NA
Text: member for South Australia, Mr Glynn,

Speaker: NA
Text: and others, who assure me that until a writ

Speaker: NA
Text: is issued a case cannot be said to be sub j u - -

Speaker: NA
Text: dice. I n order to make sure that no writ had

Speaker: NA
Text: been issued, I telegraphed to Sydney yes-

Speaker: NA
Text: a terday, and received a reply that matters

Speaker: NA
Text: had nofc yet reached that stage. I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand an application has been made in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect to an overpayment of duty, and ifc

Speaker: NA
Text: has been necessary to adopt this course,

Speaker: NA
Text: because i f the overpayment is not claimed

Speaker: NA
Text: within six months i t will be forfeited. I

Speaker: NA
Text: mention these facts in justification of my

Speaker: NA
Text: present action in bringing this matter before

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members. So far as the merits of

Speaker: NA
Text: the case are concerned, I can only give

Speaker: NA
Text: the facts as they are submitted to me.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members must see from fche

Speaker: NA
Text: petition presented to-day that a very strong

Speaker: NA
Text: case has been made out against the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Mr Goldring does not fear to have

Speaker: NA
Text: his case debated, in the f u l l light of day. He

Speaker: NA
Text: has repeatedly appealed to the Customs

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities, and lias also asked the law

Speaker: NA
Text: courts to insist thafc the Government should

Speaker: NA
Text: return his books and papers, or give some

Speaker: NA
Text: reason for retaining them. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment instructed Sir Julian Salomons to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake -their defence, and to raise the

Speaker: NA
Text: point that the courts had no jurisdiction,

Speaker: NA
Text: and as the court supported that view Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Goldring was unable to obtain any redress.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have a summary of the whole of the facts

Speaker: NA
Text: of the case which I shall proceed to lay

Speaker: NA
Text: before honorable members. I t is as fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lows :-

Speaker: NA
Text: 17fch November, 1902 -Enta y tendered for

Speaker: NA
Text: goods ex Australia on the Melbourne Customs,

Speaker: NA
Text: and duty paid, £2fi 10s. 3d.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2.1st November -Invoice s and books demanded

Speaker: NA
Text: by Customs officers in Sydney, .and same handed

Speaker: NA
Text: to bhem.

Speaker: NA
Text: 22nd November - Attended acbing-collector

Speaker: NA
Text: with batch of invoices to arrive; requested to

Speaker: NA
Text: know what was bhe trouble. Unable to get

Speaker: NA
Text: reply. Made appointmenb for 24bh.

Speaker: NA
Text: 24th November -Calle d on acting-collector,

Speaker: NA
Text: when he stated he could give me no relief, and

Speaker: NA
Text: informed me that I could not get any goods.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pointed out bhe hardship. Made many sugges-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions to get the goods, as Christmas was at hand.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ofllered guarantee or deposit to any amount re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired. Was promised that offer would be for-

Speaker: NA
Text: warded on to Melbourne, and would ask for

Speaker: NA
Text: reply by wire, as they could not entertain any

Speaker: NA
Text: offer in Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: 24th Novemberto 1st December - Called

Speaker: NA
Text: almost daily, but wibh no resulb.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 st December -Extrac t from agenb's letter re-

Speaker: NA
Text: specting goods of 17th November:-"Di d hot

Speaker: NA
Text: know reason why goods stopped. Commissioners

Speaker: NA
Text: will not receive personal interviews, and to write

Speaker: NA
Text: to Department."

Speaker: NA
Text: 5th December -Lette r to Commissioner for

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs, Melbourne, asking to be allowed to

Speaker: NA
Text: clear goods to prevent business from being

Speaker: NA
Text: brought to a standstill, on such conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: may be disposed to allow, and asking for informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion how to get bhe goods.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Never replied bo.)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sydney Smith.

Speaker: NA
Text: 9th December -Wir e to Minister for Customs,

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne : " Waiting reply ; business brought;

Speaker: NA
Text: bo standstill."

Speaker: NA
Text: (No reply.)

Speaker: NA
Text: 11th December -Wire , Minister for Customs,

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne - '' When may I expect reply to

Speaker: NA
Text: letter ?"

Speaker: NA
Text: (No reply.)

Speaker: NA
Text: 17th December -Letbe r to Commissioner for

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs, that letters unanswered ; pointing out

Speaker: NA
Text: hardship and offer to Collector of Customs,

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney. (See November 24th.)

Speaker: NA
Text: (No reply.)

Speaker: NA
Text: 19bh December - Sighb entries passed on

Speaker: NA
Text: cerbain goods in Sydney which were obtained

Speaker: NA
Text: and brought inbo warehouse. Values fixed bhe

Speaker: NA
Text: same as in our invoices.

Speaker: NA
Text: 20th December -Waite d on b3' two officers

Speaker: NA
Text: and threatened unless I handed them over goods,

Speaker: NA
Text: a search warrant would be issued and the goods

Speaker: NA
Text: seized. Poinbed out bhat I had made various

Speaker: NA
Text: offers to give bond or guarantee. Was then

Speaker: NA
Text: threatened with immediate seizure unless bond

Speaker: NA
Text: signed.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM MCMILLAN
Text: W a s that after

Speaker: NA
Text: the sight entry had been passed ?

Speaker: Mr SYDNEY SMITH
Text: Yes .

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM MCMILLAN
Text: This is surely

Speaker: NA
Text: not a civilized country 1

Speaker: Mr SYDNEY SMITH
Text: I t looks as i f

Speaker: NA
Text: we were under the law of Russia and not of

Speaker: NA
Text: a free country. I now ask honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers to listen to the next statement-

Speaker: NA
Text: Executed bond;-Th e form of bond demanded

Speaker: NA
Text: was:-" I hereby deposit--- , being amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: duty shorb paid." The endeavour was to make

Speaker: NA
Text: me incriminate myself. I refused to sign in that

Speaker: NA
Text: form, and ifc was then altered by inserting word

Speaker: NA
Text: "claimed."

Speaker: NA
Text: W i l l honorable members notice that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs authorities endeavoured to make

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Goldring incriminate himself, but he

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to sign the bond, and its form was

Speaker: NA
Text: altered by the omission of the word " paid,"

Speaker: NA
Text: and the substitution offcheword "claimed."

Speaker: NA
Text: They endeavoured fco induce Mr Goldring

Speaker: NA
Text: to incriminate himself

Speaker: Mr KINGSTON
Text: Nonsense .

Speaker: Mr SYDNEY SMITH
Text: Th e Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: will have an opportunity of contradicting

Speaker: NA
Text: me i f he can.

Speaker: Mr LE GROOM
Text: Who Was tlie officer

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned 1

Speaker: Mr SYDNEY SMITH
Text: I have not the

Speaker: NA
Text: name of the officer, but that is a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: no importance, because fche Minister is re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible. Mr Golding has nofc been able

Speaker: NA
Text: to obtain any satisfaction from the Customs

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities, and he is now appealing to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House tp grant him redress, and has the

Speaker: NA
Text: as the\' same right in that respect as any other

Speaker: NA
Text: citizen who may consider himself aggrieved.

Speaker: NA
Text: I did nofc meet Mr Goldring until after the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts of his case had been reported in the

Speaker: NA
Text: newspapers. When I referred to this mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter some weeks ago, I did not even know

Speaker: NA
Text: who Mr Goldring was. From the facts

Speaker: NA
Text: published in the press, however, I gathered

Speaker: NA
Text: that he had been very harshly treated, and

Speaker: NA
Text: subsequent]}' I obtained the information

Speaker: NA
Text: which 1 am now giving to honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers-

Speaker: NA
Text: 20th December -Waite d on by two officers and

Speaker: NA
Text: threatened unless I handed them over goods a

Speaker: NA
Text: search warrant would be issued and the goods

Speaker: NA
Text: seized. Pointed out that I had made various

Speaker: NA
Text: offers to give bond or guarantee. Was then

Speaker: NA
Text: threatened' with immediate seizure unless bond

Speaker: NA
Text: signed. Executed bond. The form of bond de-

Speaker: NA
Text: manded was : - I hereby deposit

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of duty short paid. This endeavour to

Speaker: NA
Text: make me - incriminate myself. I refused to sign

Speaker: NA
Text: in that form, and it was then altered by insertion

Speaker: NA
Text: word "claimed."

Speaker: NA
Text: 20bh December -Lette r to Melbourne agent to

Speaker: NA
Text: clear goods and offer bond.

Speaker: NA
Text: 24th December -Repl y from Melbourne agent,

Speaker: NA
Text: " Authorities could not accept, as matter not

Speaker: NA
Text: finally settled."

Speaker: NA
Text: That was on the 24th December.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Text: Of last year 1

Speaker: Mr SYDNEY SMITH
Text: Yes . .

Speaker: NA
Text: 24th December, 1902, to 27th January, 1903 -

Speaker: NA
Text: Business brought to a stand-still. Numerous re-

Speaker: NA
Text: presentations to Customs in Sydney, but they

Speaker: NA
Text: either would not or could not afford any informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. .

Speaker: NA
Text: 27th January -Sen t certain invoices to Cus-

Speaker: NA
Text: toms with the, request to be 'supplied with bond

Speaker: NA
Text: to enable goods to be cleared. Offer refused.

Speaker: NA
Text: 29th January -Sen t invoices to Customs,

Speaker: NA
Text: ney, and asked if duty paid on same could I ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain delivery. Was told " Uo." Asked for rea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons. Was told that under instructions from

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne I was not to be allowed to clear any

Speaker: NA
Text: goods.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2nd February -Presente d entry and duty for

Speaker: NA
Text: goods mentioned above. Duty was retained but

Speaker: NA
Text: entries returned. Letter from from my solicitor

Speaker: NA
Text: to Collector of Customs pointing out extreme

Speaker: NA
Text: hardship, asking for reasons for action, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: goods may be cleared on any reasonable agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Letter not replied to.

Speaker: NA
Text: 11th February -Lette r from solicitor to Col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lector of Customs complaining that letters not

Speaker: NA
Text: replied to, and threatening proceedings by man-

Speaker: NA
Text: damus ot detention.

Speaker: NA
Text: 12th February -Lette r from collector to soli-

Speaker: NA
Text: citor asking me to attend to answer questions.

Speaker: NA
Text: 16th February - Attended collector and

Speaker: NA
Text: answered questions, and requested that some

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance should be given me to enable, me to

Speaker: NA
Text: carry. Was given to understand there was no

Speaker: NA
Text: reason why I should not get my goods.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask honorable members to take special

Speaker: NA
Text: notice of that.

Speaker: Mr CONROY
Text: Wha t was the personal

Speaker: NA
Text: enmity between him and tbe Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade and Customs ?

Speaker: NA
Text: 17th February -Presente d entries for furtner

Speaker: NA
Text: goods and paid duty. Certain goods were free.

Speaker: NA
Text: Samples were taken out and shown to customers

Speaker: NA
Text: with particulars of invoiced prices.

Speaker: NA
Text: 19th February -Deliver y refused of free goods

Speaker: NA
Text: unless bond entered into. Letter to collector,

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney, asking if bond required for free goods,

Speaker: NA
Text: and protesting ogiiinst detention of same, also

Speaker: NA
Text: protesting against goods being shown to competi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tors. No reply to letter.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is to say, he complains that the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: voices of his goods were shown to his-

Speaker: NA
Text: customers.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM MCMILLAN
Text: Did the Cus-

Speaker: NA
Text: toms authorities show the cost price of the

Speaker: NA
Text: goods to his customers 1

Speaker: Mr SYDNEY SMITH
Text: I am informed

Speaker: NA
Text: being that they did. I am simply stating the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts as they have been presented to me.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members will then be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: arrive at their own conclusions after hearing

Speaker: NA
Text: the reply of the Minister for Trade and

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs.

Speaker: NA
Text: 23rd February -Lette r to collector, S3'dney,

Speaker: NA
Text: asking for reply.

Speaker: NA
Text: 25tn February -Lette r from collector that

Speaker: NA
Text: goods would be delivered on security.

Speaker: NA
Text: I pause here, because i t may be said

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Department agreed to accept

Speaker: NA
Text: a bond i n connexion with the goods; but

Speaker: NA
Text: I would point out that the letter of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 25th February relates onlyfcocertain jewel-

Speaker: NA
Text: lery and some free goods, and has no refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence whatever to the watches. Ifc has no

Speaker: NA
Text: reference to the original seizure, but was

Speaker: NA
Text: written i n reply to a communication with

Speaker: NA
Text: Sj'd- regard to free goods and certain jewellery-

Speaker: NA
Text: 25th February cable from principals-Foreig n

Speaker: NA
Text: Office will intervene at the request of Swiss-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers."

Speaker: NA
Text: That is to say, this firm actually had to

Speaker: NA
Text: appeal to the Swiss Minister- a large

Speaker: NA
Text: quantity of the goods came from Switzer-

Speaker: NA
Text: land-t o request Lord Lansdowne to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tervene and see fchafc justice was done-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Swiss Minister communicated with

Speaker: NA
Text: Lord Lansdowne, asking him to see thafc

Speaker: NA
Text: the business carried on by the firm in Aus-
